title: 1.3: Time-Based Properties
summary: Learn to use Age and Lifetime to create time-based particle effects
intro: In this lesson, you'll learn about Age and Lifetime - two fundamental concepts for creating time-based effects. Age represents how long a particle has been alive, while Lifetime is its total lifespan. By calculating the age ratio (Age / Lifetime), we can create effects that change over time, such as particles that grow or fade as they age.
steps: Create a SystemBlock - this is the root of your particle system
Create a CreateParticleBlock to emit particles
Set an initial color and size using ParticleInputBlock
Add a PointShapeBlock to emit particles from a single point
Add an UpdatePositionBlock to handle particle movement
Get Position and ScaledDirection, add them together, and connect to UpdatePositionBlock
Get the particle's Age using ParticleInputBlock with Age contextual value
Get the particle's Lifetime using ParticleInputBlock with Lifetime contextual value
Calculate the age ratio: Age / Lifetime using ParticleMathBlock with Divide operation
Add an UpdateColorBlock and connect InitialColor contextual value to it
Add an UpdateSizeBlock to change particle size over time
Calculate growth factor: 1 + ageRatio using ParticleMathBlock (Add operation)
Apply the growth factor to size calculation: baseSize * (1 + ageRatio)
Connect the final size to UpdateSizeBlock's size input
Chain the blocks: CreateParticle → PointShape → UpdatePosition → UpdateColor → UpdateSize → SystemBlock
Add a ParticleTextureSourceBlock to provide a texture
Observe how particles now grow over time based on their age

blocks.name: ParticleInputBlock (Age)
blocks.description: Retrieves the current age of a particle. Age starts at 0 when the particle is created and increases each frame until it reaches the lifetime value. Age is measured in seconds.

properties.name: contextualValue
properties.description: The type of contextual data - Age in this case

blocks.name: ParticleInputBlock (Lifetime)
blocks.description: Retrieves the total lifetime of a particle. Lifetime is a constant value set when the particle is created. It represents the maximum age a particle can reach before it dies. Lifetime is measured in seconds.

properties.name: contextualValue
properties.description: The type of contextual data - Lifetime in this case

blocks.name: ParticleMathBlock (Divide)
blocks.description: Divides two values. In this lesson, we use it to calculate the age ratio (Age / Lifetime), which gives us a value from 0 (just created) to 1 (about to die). This ratio is the foundation for all time-based effects.

blocks.name: ParticleMathBlock (Multiply)
blocks.description: Multiplies two values. Used to calculate final size by multiplying base size with a growth factor.

blocks.name: ParticleMathBlock (Add)
blocks.description: Adds two values. Used to create growth factor: 1 + ageRatio, which increases from 1.0 to 2.0 as the particle ages.

blocks.name: ParticleMathBlock (Subtract)
blocks.description: Subtracts two values. Used to calculate fade factor: 1 - ageRatio, which decreases from 1.0 to 0.0 as the particle ages.

codeCopy: This lesson introduces time-based calculations using Age and Lifetime. The age ratio (Age / Lifetime) is a value from 0 to 1 that represents how far through its life the particle is. When ageRatio = 0, the particle was just created. When ageRatio = 1, the particle is about to die. We use this ratio to create effects that change over time. For example, size = baseSize * (1 + ageRatio) makes particles grow from baseSize to 2 * baseSize as they age. The inverted ratio (1 - ageRatio) is useful for fading effects.
objectives: Understand Age and Lifetime contextual values
Calculate age ratio (Age / Lifetime) for time-based effects
Use age ratio to create particles that change over time
Apply mathematical operations to age ratio for different effects
Understand the difference between growth (1 + ageRatio) and fade (1 - ageRatio) formulas

commonMistakes.mistake: Dividing Lifetime by Age instead of Age by Lifetime
commonMistakes.explanation: The age ratio should be Age / Lifetime, not Lifetime / Age. The correct formula gives a value from 0 to 1.
commonMistakes.solution: Always divide Age by Lifetime: ageRatio = Age / Lifetime. This gives 0 when particle is created, 1 when it dies.

commonMistakes.mistake: Using Age directly without calculating ratio
commonMistakes.explanation: Age is measured in seconds and can be any value. Without dividing by Lifetime, you can't create normalized effects.
commonMistakes.solution: Always calculate the ratio first: ageRatio = Age / Lifetime. Then use this normalized value (0 to 1) for calculations.

commonMistakes.mistake: Forgetting that ageRatio increases from 0 to 1
commonMistakes.explanation: ageRatio starts at 0 (just created) and increases to 1 (about to die). Using it directly makes things grow, using (1 - ageRatio) makes them fade.
commonMistakes.solution: For growth effects, use ageRatio or (1 + ageRatio). For fade effects, use (1 - ageRatio). Remember: ageRatio goes from 0 to 1.

homework: Try different size growth formulas (e.g., baseSize * ageRatio, baseSize * (2 - ageRatio))
Experiment with fade effects using (1 - ageRatio)
Create particles that shrink over time instead of growing
Try combining growth and fade effects together
Experiment with different math operations to see how they affect the particle behavior
